Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @wookie in the whitepaper I describe various use-cases where somebody would want this stuff, such as human-rights activists or whistleblowers: https://github.com/leto/hushlist/blob/master/whitepaper/protocol.pdf

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Hushlist is compatible with any ZEC fork, which means KMD and every KMD asset chain like PIRATE

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the most basic form is just using the Zcash protocol memo field, then there are more advanced uses that use "viewing keys" and some features that only some ZEC forks might have/etc. But at it's core, every KMD AC can use Hushlist

Author: wookie#7663
Content: @dukeleto Thank you! Good examples of use cases at the end! Also good that's it's interoperable on any ZEC forks!

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I thought Zcash Sapling would be ready by now, and kind of went into a holding pattern, because Zcash was changing so many things

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but now I see many coins will never upgrade to Sapling, which *might* be ready in a few months from now, and others will take a long time, because it's not easy. So supporting "old skool" Zcash viewing keys, as the system uses now, will be around for a while

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the word on the street is, new Sapling shielded transactions are in the ~5 second range, instead of ~45 seconds, which is huge. But Zcash still does not persist their new Sapling private keys to disk (with less than 6 weeks to their block activitation), so yeah. üçø

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that is 5 seconds versus 45 seconds *per JoinSplit*

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you can currently send to up to 54 people in a z_sendmany, which means roughly 45 minutes to embed a 27KB file into a transaction

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: fine for some use cases, like if you want to prove something after the fact, but store it encrypted for a while in a blockchain. But any type of chat or real-time use case is out the window

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so Sapling support, if it ever gets delivered, makes everything a lot more usable for normal folks

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and also opens up mobile usage, right now a few shielded transactions would kill your battery

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Here is a quick thing for something to try, read this commit and make equivalent changes for PIRATE, on a `pirate` branch: https://github.com/MyHush/hush-ng/commit/cabd6a30ab29d8050c0f5c51081108af87fce739

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that will let you see how Hush-NG works with PIRATE, and it will let you read and send encrypted memos

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: if you try to use a taddr with PIRATE, some RPC error will pop up to tell you that is not allowed on PIRATE. Hush-NG has very good error-handling and gives you nice notifications with details

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: even better would be a drop-down that let's you choose which coin to connect to. If PIRATE wants a PIRATE-centric wallet, then most of the work is making binaries for people, because most people don't want to git clone from github

Author: abcd#1803
Content: Net hash is a representation of difficulty

Author: abcd#1803
Content: If we get really lucky and find 10 blocks back to back, diff will rise and in turn nethash will appear higher than it is

Author: abcd#1803
Content: Same goes for if you are unlucky, nethash can sometimes be lower than actual hashrate.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: basically, if blocks are coming in in <1 minute intervals, that number is lower than actual network hash rate. If blocks are coming in >1 minute intervals, that number is higher than actual network hash rate

Author: Alright#0419
Content: the estimate is based on block times and difficulty

Author: abcd#1803
Content: Most likely a few others had the same thing happen
